General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1

Select the option in which the numbers shares the same relationship in set as that shared by the numbers in the given set.(NOTE: Operations should be performed on the whole numbers, without breaking down the numbers into its constituent digits. E.g.13 – Operations on 13 such as adding /subtracting /multiplying etc. to 13 can be performed. Breaking down 13 into 1 and 3 and then performing mathematical operations on 1 and 3 is not allowed)

(12, 28, 8)

(72, 48, 12)

(63, 36, 17)
(119, 29, 55)
(108, 58, 25)
More than one of the above.
None of the above
Solution

The logic followed here is:

Logic: Third Number = (Difference between first and second number) ÷ 2

(12, 28, 8):

→ 8 = (28 - 12) ÷ 2

→ 8 = 16 ÷ 2

(72, 48, 12):

→ 12 = (72 - 48) ÷ 2

→ 12 = 24 ÷ 2

Let's check each option as per the logic,

1) (63, 36, 17):

→ 17 = (63 - 36) ÷ 2

→ 17 ≠ 27 ÷ 2 

2) (119, 29, 55):

→ 55 = (119 - 29) ÷ 2

→ 55 ≠ 90 ÷ 2

3) (108, 58, 25):

→ 25 = (108 - 58) ÷ 2

→ 25 = 50 ÷ 2 ⇒ Follow the logic.

Here, we can see that only Option 3 follow the logic.

Hence, the correct answer is "(108, 58, 25)".

General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1
In question given below find the odd one from the given responses.
XKE9
ULD5
ZAT5 
YGA17
JBC5
Solution

According to the positional values of the alphabets,

1) XKE9 → X – K – E = 24 – 11 – 5 = 8 and not 9. This is odd.

2) ULD5 → U – L – D = 21 – 12 – 4 = 5

3) ZAT5 → Z – A – T = 26 – 1 – 20 = 5

4) YGA17 → Y – G – A = 25 – 7 – 1 = 17

5) JBC5 → J - B - C = 10 - 2 - 3 = 5

Hence, the odd one among the given options is XKE9.

General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1

Three of the given four figures are similar in a certain manner while one is different. Pick the odd one out.

B
C
D
A
None of these
Solution

The logic is:

A → Number of lines in the outside figure is 4 while the number of lines inside the figure is 3. So, the number of lines in the outside and inside figure is not equal.

B → Number of lines in the outside figure is 3 while the number of lines inside the figure is 3. So, the number of lines in the outside and inside figure is equal.

C → Number of lines in the outside figure is 5 while the number of lines inside the figure is 5. So, the number of lines in the outside and inside figure is equal.

D → Number of lines in the outside figure is 6 while the number of lines inside the figure is 6. So, the number of lines in the outside and inside figure is equal.

Hence, 'A' is the odd one out.

General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1
The second number in the given number pairs is obtained by performing certain mathematical operation(s) on the first number. The same operation(s) are followed in all the number pairs except one. Find that odd number pair.
4328 : 8324
2437 : 7342
3569 : 9653
1786 : 6871 
None of these
Solution

The logic followed here is: 

The second number is first number written backwards.

1) 4328 : 8324 → 4328 → backwards → 8234 ≠ 8324

2) 2437 : 7342 → 2437 → backwards → 7342

3) 3569 : 9653 → 3569 → backwards → 9653

4) 1786 : 6871 → 1786 → backwards → 6871

Hence, option 1) is the odd one.

General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1

Select the combination of letters that when sequentially placed in the blanks of the given series will complete the series.

r _ l _ q r p _ b q _ p l b _ r _ l _ q

p, b, l, r, q, p, b
p, p, l, b, r, q, b
p, l, b, q, r, b, p
​l, p, q, b, r, p, b 
None of above
Solution

By checking options:

(1) p, b, l, r, q, p, b → r p l b q / r p l b q / r p l b q / r p l b q

Here r p l b q is repeated.

(2) p, p, l, b, r, q, b → r p l p q / r p l b q / b p l b r / r q l b q

(3) p, l, b, q, r, b, p → r p l l q / r p b b q / q p l b r / r b l p q

(4) ​l, p, q, b, r, p, b → r l l p q / r p q b q / b p l b r / r p l b q

Option (1) gives a pattern of r p l b q - r p l b q - r p l b q - r p l b q.

Hence, p, b, l, r, q, p, b is the correct answer.

General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1

Find the wrong number in the series. 

20, 33, 50, 69, 92, 100

33
55
20
100
92
Solution

 

Given:

20, 33, 50, 69, 92, 100

Calculation:

the given series follows the following pattern:

20 + 13 = 33

33 + 17 = 50

50 + 19 = 69

69 + 23 = 92

92 + 29 = 121

here; 13 , 17 , 19 , 23 & 29 are prime numbers.

∴ 121 will come in place of 100 and 100 is wrong number in the series.

General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1

If M denotes '-', N denotes '÷', O denotes '×' and P denotes '+' then what will be the value of the given expression?

32 O 18 P 92 N (√1089 M √100) M 316 N 2

529
108
422
349
109
Solution

The pattern followed here is: 

Alphabet given O P M N
Mathematical sign × + -  ÷ 

Given: 32 O 18 P 92 N (√1089 M √100) M 316 N 2

⇒ 32 × 18 + 92 ÷ (√1089 - √100) - 316 ÷ 2

⇒ 32 × 18 + 92 ÷ (33 - 10) - 316 ÷ 2

⇒ 32 × 18 + 92 ÷ 23 - 316 ÷ 2

⇒ 32 × 18 + 4 - 158

⇒ 576 + 4 - 158

⇒ 580 - 158

⇒ 422

Hence, the correct answer is "422".

General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1

Three statements are given, followed by three conclusions numbered I, II and III.Assuming the statements to be true, even if they seem to be at variance with commonly known facts, decide which of the conclusions logically follow(s) from the statements.

Statements:

No cup is a plate.

All cups are utensils.

Some bottles are cups.

Conclusions:

I. Some utensils are not plates.

II. Some bottles are not plates.

III. No bottle is a plate.

Only conclusions I and II follow
Only conclusions II and III follow
All conclusions follow
Only conclusions I and III follow
none of above
Solution

The least possible Venn diagram for the given statements is as shown below :

 

Conclusions:

I. Some utensils are not plates → Follow (As all cups are utensils and no cup is a plate. So, as direct negative or cross relation is given between plates and cups which whole comes in utensils therefore it is definitely true)

II. Some bottles are not plates → Follow (As some bottles are cups and no cup is a plate. So, a direct negative or cross relation is given between plates and cups which has some part common with bottles therefore it is definitely true)

III. No bottle is a plate → Does not follow (As some bottles are cups and no cup is a plate. So, as no direct negative or cross relation is given between plates and bottles therefore it is definitely false)

∴ Here, Only conclusions I and II follow.​

Hence, the correct answer is "Only conclusions I and II follow".

Additional Information

Conditions of either or case

  1. The elements should be same in both conclusions.

  2. Both conclusions should be possible but not definitely true.

  3. One of the conclusions should be negative and one of the conclusions should be positive i.e complimentary pair.

  4. Complimentary pairs :

  • ​some + no and all + some not

  • Some + Some not and All + no are not Complimentary pair.

General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1

Which of the following interchange of numbers and mathematical signs would make the given equation correct?

72 ÷ 6 − 20 + 30 × 5 = 70

5 and 20, − and ×
20 and 30, × and ÷
5 and 70, + and −
6 and 20, + and ÷
none of above
Solution

Given statement : 72 ÷ 6 − 20 + 30 × 5 = 70

According to the question, after interchanging the given signs and numbers :

So,

  • Option - (1) : 5 and 20, − and ×

Given statement : 72 ÷ 6 − 20 + 30 × 5 = 70

after interchanging the given signs and numbers :

72 ÷ 6 × 5 + 30 - 20 = 70

12 × 5 + 30 - 20 = 70

60 + 30 - 20 = 70

90 - 20 = 70

70 = 70 (LHS = RHS)

  • Option - (2) : 20 and 30, × and ÷

 

Given statement : 72 ÷ 6 − 20 + 30 × 5 = 70

after interchanging the given signs and numbers :

72 × 6 − 30 + 20 ÷ 5 = 70

72 × 6 − 30 + 4 = 70

432 + 4 - 30 = 70

436 - 30 = 70

406 ≠ 70 (LHS ≠ RHS)

  • Option - (3) : 5 and 70, + and −

 

Given statement : 72 ÷ 6 − 20 + 30 × 5 = 70

after interchanging the given signs and numbers :

72 ÷ 6 + 20 - 30 × 70 = 5

12 + 20 - 30 × 70 = 5

12 + 20 - 2100 = 5

32 - 2100 = 5

- 2068 ≠ 5 (LHS ≠ RHS)

  • Option - (4) : 6 and 20, + and ÷

 

Given statement : 72 ÷ 6 − 20 + 30 × 5 = 70

after interchanging the given signs and numbers :

72 + 20 − 6 ÷ 30 × 5 = 70

72 + 20 − 0.2 × 5 = 70

72 + 20 - 1 = 70

92 - 1 = 70

91 ≠ 70 (LHS ≠ RHS)

Hence, "Option - (1)" is the correct answer.

General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1

A # B means ‘A is the sister of B’.

A @ B means ‘A is the son of B’.

A & B means ‘A is the father of B’.

A % B means ‘A is the mother of B’.

If W @ Q % T & Y @ M % K, then how is W related to K?

Father
Mother’s brother
Father’s brother
Brother
Sister
Solution

Given :

A is

Symbol

#

@

&

 %

Meaning

Sister

Son

Father

 Mother

to B

Given statement : W @ Q % T & Y @ M % K

So,

  • W @ Q → W is the son of Q.

  • Q % T → Q is the mother of T.

  • T & Y → T is the father of Y.

  • Y @ M → Y is the son of M.

​

  • M % K → M is the mother of K.

​

Thus, according to the final family tree, W is the paternal uncle i.e father's brother of K.

Hence, "Father’s brother" is the correct answer.

Who is sitting at the immediate right of B?
Y
C
D
X
A
Solution

Eight people A, B, C, D, W, X, Y, and Z were sitting around the circular table facing inward with equal distance.

1) Y sits third to the right of Z and third to the left of X.

2) C sits second to the right of W who was not the neighbor of X.

3) A sits second to the right of B and second to the left of D.  

Hence, X is sitting at the immediate right of B.

Direction: In the following question, a given question is followed by information in two statements. You have to decide the data in which statement(s) is sufficient to answer the question and mark your answer accordingly.
What is the code of ‘blue’?
I. In a certain language, ‘sky is blue’ is coded as ‘ab cb pf’ and ‘old is gold’ is coded as ‘er pf gh’
II. In a certain language, ‘teacher is coming’ is coded as ‘pf it ch’ and ‘teacher has blue book’ coded as ‘ab hy jo ch’ 
Statement I alone is sufficient 
Statement II alone is sufficient 
Both I and II are required
Statement I and II both are not sufficient to answer
Either statement is sufficient to answer 
Solution
Statement I:
In a certain language, ‘sky is blue’ is coded as ‘ab cb pf’, and ‘old is gold’ is coded as ‘er pf gh’
so statement I alone is not sufficient.
Statement II:
In a certain language, ‘teacher is coming’ is coded as ‘pf it ch’ and ‘teacher has blue book’ coded as ‘ab hy jo ch’, statement II alone is not sufficient.
Combining statement I and II:
the code for the word ‘blue’ is ‘ab’.
Hence, both the statements are required to give an answer.

Statements:  A = B > C = D < F < G > H 

Conclusions:

I. A > D

II. C > G
Only I follow
Only II follow
Both follow
Either I or II follow
Neither I nor II follow
Solution

Given statements: A = B > C = D < F < G > H 

Conclusions:

I. A > D →True (as A = B > C = D, so, specific relation can be obtained between A and D)

II. C > G → False (as C = D < F < G, so, Here C > G will not be correct.)

Only I follow.

General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1

Direction: In the following question, assuming the given statement to be true, find which of the conclusion(s) among the given conclusions is/are definitely true, and then give your answers accordingly.

Statement:

N ≥ M ≥ L = A, D > C ≥ A

Conclusions:

I. N > C

II. L ≥ D

Only I follows
Only Il follows
Both I and II follows
Either I or II follows
Neither I nor II follows
Solution

Given statements: N ≥ M ≥ L = A, D > C ≥ A

On combining: N ≥ M ≥ L = A ≤ C < D

Conclusions:

I. N > C → False (as N ≥ M ≥ L = A ≤ C, so no definite relationship can be determined between N and C.)

II. L ≥ D → False (as L = A ≤ C < D, so D is greater than L and not L is greater than or equal to D.)

There is no direct relation given between N and C so the first conclusion doesn't follow. L is smaller than D so the second conclusion also doesn't follow.

Hence, the correct answer is Neither I nor II follows.

Direction: In the following question, assuming the given statement to be true, find which of the conclusion(s) among the given conclusions is/are definitely true, and then give your answers accordingly.

Statement:

A ≥ D > N > Q < I, Q > U ≥ S

Conclusions:

I. I > S

II. D ≥ U

Only I follows
Only Il follows
Both I and II follows
Either I or II follows
Neither I or II follows
Solution

Given statements: A ≥ D > N > Q < I, Q > U ≥ S

On combining: A ≥ D > N > Q > U ≥ S, I > Q > U ≥ S

Conclusions:

I. I > S → True (as I > Q > U ≥ S, so it is definite that I is greater than S.)

II. D ≥ U → False (as D > N > Q > U, so D is greater than U but not equal to U.)

It can be directly concluded that I is greater than S so the first conclusion follows. D is not greater than or equal to U so the second conclusion doesn't follow.

Hence, the correct answer is Only I follows.

General Intelligence & Reasoning

Direction: In the question below are given three statements followed by two conclusions numbered I and II. You have to take the given statements to be true even if they seem to be at variance with commonly known facts. Read all the conclusions and then decide which of the given conclusions logically follows from the given statements disregarding commonly known facts.

Statements:

Some Ice is Milk.

All Ice is Tea.

Only a few Tea is Coffee.

Conclusions:

I. All Tea can be Coffee.

II. All coffee can be Tea.

Only I follows
Only II follows
Both I and II follows
Either I or II follows
Neither I nor II follows
Solution

The least possible Venn Diagram will be as follows:

Conclusions:

I. All Tea can be Coffee → False (As Only a few Tea is Coffee, some tea is coffee and some tea is not coffee so All tea can be coffee will be false)

II. All coffee can be Tea → True (As Only a few Tea is Coffee, some tea is coffee and some tea is not coffee. The relation of some not is only from the tea side so there is a possibility that all coffee can be tea, so it is true)

The diagram of possibility will be as follows:

Hence, only II follows.

Note:

1. 'Can be' means a possibility.

2. 'Only a few' means a relation of Some and Some Not of the first element with the second element.

General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1

Directions: In the question given below, there is a statement followed by two assumptions numbered I and II. An assumption is something supposed or taken for granted. You have to consider the statement and assumptions and then decide which of the assumption(s) is/are implicit in the statement. You have to consider the statements to be true even if they seem to be at variance from commonly known facts.

Statement: Now  a days most of the people are suffering from many life style diseases such as, obesity, blood pressure, diabetes etc. 

Assumptions: 

I) Tendency of eating junk food is increasing.
II) People have a lot of pressure in their working life.

If only Assumption I is implicit.
If only Assumption II is implicit.
If either Assumption I or II is implicit.
If both Assumption I and II are implicit.
If neither Assumption I nor II is implicit. 
Solution

Both the assumptions are correct as lifestyle diseases are caused due to adaptation of poor lifestyle like eating junk food, and excessive work load, and lack of proper nutrients etc.

Hence, both Assumption I and II are implicit.

40
General Intelligence & Reasoning
+1
Directions: One/two statements are given followed by two conclusions I and II. You have to consider the two statements to be true even if they seem to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given conclusions, if any, follow from the given statements.

Statement: Rakesh is senior to Rajesh, and Rajesh is senior to Rahul.

Conclusions:

i. Rakesh is senior to Rahul.

ii. Rahul is not senior to Rakesh.

Both conclusion (i) and (ii) follow
Neither conclusion (i) nor (ii) follows
Only conclusion (i) follows
Only conclusion (ii) follows
Either conclusion (i) or (ii) follows
Solution

The logic followed is:

Given statement: Rakesh is senior to Rajesh and Rajesh is senior to Rahul.

Rakesh > Rajesh > Rahul

Conclusion:

I. Rakesh is senior to Rahul means Rakesh > Rahul

So, Conclusion I follows.

II. Rahul is not senior to Rakesh means Rakesh > Rahul

So, conclusion II follows.

Hence, the correct answer is "Both conclusion (i) and (ii) follow".

General Awareness
+1
Tilak formed his Home Rule League in 1916 at
Satara
Pune
Belgaon
Berar
Nasik
Solution

The correct answer is Belgaon.

  • Tilak formed his Home Rule League in 1916 at Belgaon.

Key Points

  •  Home Rule Movement (1916 AD):
    • The Home Rule League was pioneered on the lines of a similar movement in Ireland.
    • The Muslim League also supported the movement.
  • Tilak’s Home Rule Movement:
    • It started in April 1916 AD at Belgaon. Tilak’s league was to work in Maharashtra, Karnataka, Central Province and Berar, excluding Bombay.
    • Tilak set up his Indian Home Rule League in April 1916. Tilak held his first Home Rule meeting at Belgaum. Poona was the headquarters of his league.
    • Josef Baptista became the President and N.C. Kelkar secretary.
    • He gave the slogan ‘Swaraj is my birthright and I shall have it'.
    • Tilak’s newspapers Maratha and Kesari were the organs for home rule.
  • Annie Basant’s Home Rule Movement:
    • Started with Subramaniya Iyer in Adyar in September, worked in the rest of India.
    • Annie Besant’s newspapers New India, and Commonwealth became important for this movement. 

Additional Information

  • Bal Gangadhar Tilak:
    • He launched two newspapers–the Kesari (in Marathi) and the Maratha (in English). He organised Ganpati Festival (1893 AD) and Shivajiv Festival (1895 AD).
    • He was deported to Mandalay Jail (Burma) for writing seditious articles. He started the Home Rule League in 1916 AD.
    • He was awarded the title of Lokmanya.
    • He was called ‘Bal’, Lala Lajpat Rai was called ‘Lal’ and Bipin Chandra Pal was called ‘Pal’.
    • He was a part of the trio of ‘Lal-Bal- Pal’ and the extremist group.
    • He wrote the books The Arctic Home of Vedas and Gita Rahasya.

General Awareness
+1
The Government of India releases MSP of agricultural produce from time to time. What is the full form of MSP?
Minimum Selling Price
Minimum Support Price
Maximum Selling Price
Maximum Support Price
Minimum Stock Price
Solution

The Correct Answer is Minimum Support Price.
Key Points

Minimum Support Price

  • Minimum Support Price (MSP) is a form of market intervention by the Government of India to insure agricultural producers against any sharp fall in farm prices.
  • The minimum support prices are announced by the Government of India at the beginning of the sowing season for certain crops.
  • The MSP is decided based on the recommendations of the Commission for Agricultural Costs and Prices (CACP).

 Additional Information

  • The government announces minimum support prices (MSPs) for 22 mandated crops and fair and remunerative price (FRP) for sugarcane.
  • The list of crops is as follows.
    • Cereals (7) - paddy, wheat, barley, jawar, bajra, maize, and ragi
    • Pulses (5) - gram, arhar/tur, moong, urad, and lentil
    • Oilseeds (8) - groundnut, rapeseed/mustard, toria, soybean, sunflower seed, sesamum, safflower seed, and nigerseed
    • Raw cotton
    • Raw jute

General Awareness
+1
Where was the second Buddhist Council held?
Kundalvana
Vaishali
Rajgriha
Pataliputra
Jammu
Solution

The correct answer is Vaishali.

Key Points

  • Siddhartha, also known as Gautama was the founder of Buddhism.
  • He was born about 2500 years ago.
  • The Buddha belonged to the Sakya gana and was a Kshatriya.
  • Buddhist councils were the assemblies convened in the centuries following the death of Buddha to recite texts of scriptures and to settle doctrinal disputes.
  • Six Buddhist councils were held altogether.
  • The second Buddhist council was held at Vaishali under the patronage of King Kalasoka.
  • The council was held under the presidency of Sabakami.
  • This council was held in 383 BC.

 Thus, we can say that the Second Buddhist Council was held at Vaishali.

Additional Information

  • the first Buddhist Council was held at Rajgriha in 483 BC.
  • The third Buddhist Council was held at Pataliputra in 250 BC.
  • The fourth Buddhist Council was held at Kundalvana in AD 72.
44
General Awareness
+1
If the angle between force and displacement is _______, then the work done is negative.
​45°
0
90°
180°
60°
Solution

The correct answer is 180°.

Key Points

  • Work done can be positive, negative, or zero. When a body is being lifted in the upward direction, the force of gravity is acting in the downward direction.
  • But, the displacement of the body is in the upward direction. Since the angle between the force and displacement is 180 degrees, the work done by the gravitational force on the body is negative.
  • Hence for negative work done, the angle between force and displacement is 180°.

Additional Information

  • Work is a scalar quantity. It is calculated as W = F × s c o s θ, where θ is the angle between the force applied and the displacement.
  • F and s are the force applied and the displacement respectively.
  • When 0 ∘ < θ < 90 ∘ , the value of cos θ is greater than 0 and less than 1, the work done is positive.
  • When 90 ∘ < θ < 270 ∘, the value of cos θ is negative. So work done becomes negative.
  • When cos θ = 90°, the value of cos θ is zero and so the work done is always zero.

Important Points

General Awareness
+1
Shambhu Maharaj was a renowned personality associated with which of the following dance forms?
Kathakali
Odissi
Manipuri
Kathak
Bharatnatayam
Solution

The correct answer is Kathak.

Key Points

  • Shambhu Maharaj was a renowned personality associated with Kathak dance forms.
  • Shambhu Maharaj
    • He was a Guru of the Indian classical dance form, Kathak, which belongs to Uttar Pradesh.
    • He belongs to Lucknow Gharana.
    • He received training from his father Kalka Prasad Maharaj, uncle Bindadin Maharaj and his eldest brother Achchan Maharaj.
    • Dancer Lachhu Maharaj was also his elder brother.
    • In 1952, he joined the Bharatiya Kala Kendra (later, the Kathak Kendra), New Delhi.
    • He was awarded the Padma Shri in 1956 and the Sangeet Natak Akademi Fellowship in 1967.​

​

Important Points

  • Kathak is the classical dance of Uttar Pradesh.
  • Kathak is considered to have originated from the acts of priests during the prayers in the temple.
  • This dance was greatly developed in the royal court of the last Nawab of Awadh, Wajid Ali Shah.
  • The period of Nawab Wajid Ali Shah who himself was a Kathak dancer was known as the Golden Age of Art of Awadh.

Additional Information

+1
Which of the following is incorrectly matched?
Santhal rebellion: Jharkhand
Mappila Rebellion : Kerala
Rangpur rebellion: Bihar
Deccan Uprising: Maharashtra
None of the above
Solution

The correct answer is the Rangpur rebellion: Bihar.

Key Points

Santhal Rebellion:

  • ​​​​It was a rebellion against both the British colonial authority and zamindars by the Santhal people.
  • Leaders: Sidhu, Kahnu, Chand, and Bhairav
  • Location: Jharkhand
  • The rebellion was suppressed and largely shadowed by other rebellions.

Mappila Rebellion:

  • Mappila uprising was a sequence of rebellions by the Mappila Muslims of the Malabar region of Kerala against Hindu landlords.
  • The main reasons behind the rebellion were the increase in land tax, the security of tenure, and exploitation of the poor peasantry by the landlords.
  • It resulted in Hindu-Muslim animosity.
  • The 1921 rebellion was a manifestation of long-lasting agrarian dissatisfaction.
  • Location: Malabar (Kerala)

Rangpur Rebellion:

  • Rangpur rebellion took place in Bengal.
  • It uncovered the evils like the Ijaradari scheme of peasants' exploitation.
  • It resulted in a permanent land settlement.
  • Location: Ranchi, Hazaribagh, Palamau and Manbhum.

​Deccan Uprising - 

  • Along with the Permanent Settlement, the British extended their presence beyond Bengal.
  • Ryotwari Settlement was the revenue system that was introduced in the Bombay Deccan region
  • The revolt started in Poona and henceforth it spread to Ahmednagar.
  • This uprising also involved a social boycott of the moneylender.
  • In May and June 1875, peasants of Maharashtra in some parts of Pune and Ahmednagar districts revolted against increasing agrarian distress.
  • The Deccan Riots of 1875 targeted conditions of debt peonage (kamiuti) to moneylenders.  
  • The peasants began a systematic attack on the moneylenders’ houses and shops.

General Awareness
+1
Employment figures of a country are based on data collected from 5-yearly survey on employment and unemployment. Which organisation conducts this survey?
NSSO—National Sample Survey Organisation
NREGA 2005—National Rural Employment Guarantee Act, 2005
ILO — International Labour Organisation
Census of India
None of these
Solution

The correct answer is NSSO—National Sample Survey Organisation.

  • NSSO is the central statistical agency of the Government mandated under the Statistical Services Act 1980 under the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation.
  • It is responsible for the development of arrangements for providing statistical information services to meet the needs of the Government and other users for information on which to base policy, planning, monitoring and management decisions.
  • Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) is India’s first computer-based survey launched by the National Statistical Office (NSO) in 2017.
  • It has been constituted based on the recommendation of a committee headed by Amitabh Kundu.
  • PLFS has two objective:
    • To estimate the key employment and unemployment indicators (viz. Worker Population Ratio, Labour Force Participation Rate, Unemployment Rate) in the short time interval of three months for the urban areas only in the Current Weekly Status (CWS).
    • To estimate employment and unemployment indicators in both usual status and CWS in both rural and urban areas annually.
  • Before PLFS, the NSSO (previous name of NSO) used to bring the data related to employment and unemployment based on its quinquennial (every 5 year) household socio-economic survey programme.

+1
Who determines the policy interest rate required to achieve the inflation target?
Central Bank of India
Technical Advisory Committee (TAC)
World Economic Forum (WEF)
Monetary Policy Committee (MPC)
None of the above
Solution

the correct answer is the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC).

Key Points

  • The policy interest rate required to achieve the inflation target is decided by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC). MPC is a six-member committee constituted by the Central Government (Section 45ZB of the amended RBI Act, 1934). The MPC is required to meet at least four times a year.

  • ​What Is Inflation Targeting?
    • Inflation targeting is a central banking policy that revolves around adjusting monetary policy to achieve a specified annual rate of inflation. The principle of inflation targeting is based on the belief that long-term economic growth is best achieved by maintaining price stability, and price stability is achieved by controlling inflation.
    • Inflation targeting is a central bank strategy of specifying an inflation rate as a goal and adjusting monetary policy to achieve that rate. 
    • Inflation targeting primarily focuses on maintaining price stability but is also believed by its proponents to support economic growth and stability. 
    • Inflation targeting can be contrasted to other possible policy goals of central banking, including the targeting of exchange rates, unemployment, or national income     .
  • Six MPC members
    • Ashima Goyal.
    • Shashanka Bhide.
    • Jayanth R. Varma.
    • Shaktikanta Das.
    • Mridul Saggar
    • Michael Debabrata Patra

Important Points

  • What is Inflation?
    •  Inflation refers to the rise in the prices of most goods and services of daily or common use, such as food, clothing, housing, recreation, transport, consumer staples, etc.
    • Inflation measures the average price change in a basket of commodities and services over time.
    • The opposite and rare fall in the price index of this basket of items is called ‘deflation’.
    • Inflation is indicative of the decrease in the purchasing power of a unit of a country’s currency. This could ultimately lead to a deceleration in economic growth.
    • However, a moderate level of inflation is required in the economy to ensure that production is promoted.

  • Rajaji National Park is predominantly formed from dense green jungles, and this environment forms a habitat for a number of animals.
  • The park is at the northwestern limit of distribution for both elephants and tigers in India.

Which of the following sets of taxes belongs to Central Government?
Excise duty, Sales tax and Custom duty
Income tax, Customs duty and House tax
Excise duty, Customs duty and Income tax
Custom duty, Entertainment tax and Income tax
Excise duty, Customs duty and House tax
Solution

The correct answer is Excise duty, Customs duty, and Income tax.

Key Points

  • The taxing powers of the central government encompass taxes on income (except agricultural income), excise on goods produced (other than alcohol), customs duties, and inter-state sale of goods.
  • The authority to levy a tax is coming from the Constitution which allocates the power to levy various taxes between the Centre and the State.
  • Excise Duty:
    • It refers to the taxes levied on the manufacture of goods within the country.
    • Excise duty is levied by the central government except on some items such as narcotics and alcohol.
  • Customs Duty:
    • It refers to the tax imposed on goods when they are transported across international borders.
  •  Income Tax:
    • It is a type of tax that governments impose on income generated by businesses and individuals within their jurisdiction.

Additional Information

  • Sales Tax:
    • It is a tax paid to a governing body for the sales of certain goods and services. 
  • House tax or Property tax:
    • It is the annual amount paid by a landowner to the local government or the municipal corporation of his area.
    • The property includes all tangible real estate property, his house, office building, and the property he has rented to others.
  • Entertainment Tax:
    • It is also sometimes referred to as "Amusement tax"
    • It is a tax levied on any form of commercial entertainment, such as movie tickets, exhibitions, sports events, and more.

By which Constitutional Amendment Act was the voting age lowered from 21 years to 18 years?
42nd Amendment 1976
44th Amendment 1978
52nd Amendment 1985
61st Amendment 1988
81st Amendment 1988
Solution

The Correct Answer is 61st Amendment 1988.

Link : https://legislative.gov.in/constitution-sixty-first-amendment-act-1988

Key Points

  • The Constitution (Sixty-first Amendment) Act, 1988, amended the Indian Constitution to lower the voting age for elections to the Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies from 21 to 18 years.
  • Article 326 of the Constitution, which regulates Lok Sabha and Assemblies elections, was amended to do this.
  • The Constitution (Sixty-first Amendment) Act, 1988 was introduced in the Lok Sabha as the Constitution (Sixty-second Amendment) Bill, 1988 on December 13, 1988. (Bill No. 129 of 1988). B. Shankaranand, the then-Minister of Water Resources, launched it.
  • Elections to the House of People and the Legislative Assembly of each State must be conducted on the basis of adult suffrage, which means that a person must be at least 21 years old, according to Article 326 of the Constitution.
  • The Lok Sabha discussed the bill on the 14th and 15th of December 1988, and it was passed on the 15th, after introducing a formal amendment to replace the term "Sixty-second" in Clause 1 of the bill with "Sixty-first."
  • The Rajya Sabha discussed the bill on December 16, 19, and 20, 1988, and passed it on December 20, 1988, after accepting the Lok Sabha's amendment.
  • The bill received the presidential assent on 28th March 1989 when the then President R Venkataraman assented it.
  • Thus, the act came into force on 28th March 1989.

Important Points

Amendment Explanation
42nd Amendment 1976 The Indian National Congress government led by Indira Gandhi enacted the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976, during the Emergency (25 June 1975 – 21 March 1977).
44th Amendment 1978 The Janata Party, which had won the 1977 general elections on a pledge to "restore the Constitution to the state it was in before the Emergency," enacted the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978.
52nd Amendment 1985 The Tenth Schedule to the Indian Constitution was adopted to solve the perceived issue of uncertainty in India's Parliamentary System of Government caused by democratically elected legislators.

General Awareness
+1
 The Income Tax in India is
Indirect and Progressive
Indirect and Proportional
Direct and Proportional
Direct and Progressive
None of the given option 
Solution

The correct answer is Direct and Progressive.
Key Points 

  • Income tax is a Direct tax.
  • Direct taxes are progressive, because it is possible to help more people who do not earn as much, and at the same time, mobilize resources from those who earn well. This is what makes them progressive.
  • This is the tax that is levied on the annual income or the profits which are directly paid to the government.
  • Everyone who earns any kind of income is liable to pay income tax.
  • A progressive tax imposes a higher rate on the rich than on the poor. It's based on the taxpayer's income or wealth. It's done to help lower-income families pay for basics like shelter, food, and transportation.
  •  A progressive tax allows them to spend a larger share of their incomes on the cost of living expenses.
  • Examples of progressive tax include investment income taxes, tax on interest earned, rental earnings, estate tax, and tax credits.

General Awareness
+1

The transactions in goods, services and assets between residents of a country with the rest of the world for a specified time period is known as -

Export
Import
Balance of Payments
Foreign exchange
None of the above
Solution

The correct answer is Balance of Payments.

Key Points

  • Balance of Payments - 
    • The balance of payments (BoP) records the transactions in goods, services and assets between residents of a country with the rest of the world for a specified time period typically a year. Hence statement 3 is correct.
    • There are two main accounts in the BoP – the current account and the capital account.
    • The current account records exports and imports in goods and services and transfer payments.
    • When exports exceed imports, there is a trade surplus and when imports exceed exports there is a trade deficit.
    • Trade-in services denoted as invisible trade (because they are not seen to cross national borders).
    • The balance of exports and imports of goods is referred to as the trade balance. Adding trade in services and net transfers to the trade balance, we get the current account balance.
    • The capital account records all international purchases and sales of assets such as money, stocks, bonds, etc.
    • We note that any transaction resulting in a payment to foreigners is entered as a debit and is given a negative sign. Any transaction resulting in a receipt from foreigners is entered as a credit and is given a positive sign. 

Important Points

  • Export - Exports are the goods and services produced in one country and purchased by residents of another country.
  • Import - An import is a good or service bought in one country that was produced in another country.
  • Foreign exchange - Foreign Exchange (forex or FX) is the trading of one currency for another.

Which of the following dynasties ruled before the Tughluq Dynasty?
Khilji dynasty
Sayyid dynasty
Lodi dynasty
Mughal dynasty
Slave dynasty
Solution

The correct answer is the Khilji dynasty.

Key Points

  • The time period of the Khilji Dynasty was from (1290-1320 AD).
  • The Khilji dynasty was founded by Jalaluddin Khilji.
  • Alauddin Khilji, a nephew of Jalaluddin Khilji hatched a conspiracy and got Sultan Jalaluddin killed and proclaimed himself as the Sultan in 1296.
  • Alauddin Khilji was the first Muslim ruler whose empire covered almost the whole of India up to its extreme south. 
  • He fought many battles, conquered Gujarat, Ranthambhor, Chittor, Malwa, and Deccan. During his reign of 20 years.
  • Allauddin died in 1316 A.D., and with his death, the Khilji dynasty came to an end.

Additional Information

Dynasty detailed description
Sayyid dynasty Sayyid dynasty was founded by Khizar Khan.  The Sayyids ruled from about 1414 A.D. to 1450 A.D. Khizar Khan ruled for about 37 years. Last in the Sayyid dynasty was Muhammad-bin-Farid. During his reign, there was confusion and revolts. The empire came to an end in 1451 A.D. with his death.
Lodi dynasty Bahlol Lodi was the founder of the Lodi dynasty. He was one of the Afghan Sardar. He established himself in Punjab after the invasion of Timur. Sikander Lodi was the son of Bahlol Lodi who conquered Bihar and Western Bengal. he shifted his capital from Delhi to Agra, a city founded by him. he introduced the Gazi-i- Sikandar of 32 digits for measuring cultivated fields.
Mughal dynasty Babur was the founder of the Mughal dynasty. He confronted and defeated Lodhi in 1526 at the first battle of Panipat, and so came to establish the Mughal Empire in India. Babar ruled until 1530 and was succeeded by his son Humayun.

Which part of the Constitution of India deals with the duties of citizens?
Part IVA
Part Il
Part X
Part Ill
Part V
Solution

The correct answer is Part IVA.

Key Points

  • Part IVA
    • Part IVA of the Indian Constitution relates to Fundamental Duties and is given in article-51 (a).
    • Fundamental Duties are taken from the Constitution of Russia.
    • The Fundamental Duties of citizens were added to the Constitution by the 42nd Amendment in 1976 on behalf of the Swaran Singh Committee recommendations.
    • These duties tell us of the national aims & the basic models of political order and they also motivate us to learn a sense of social responsibility.
    • Originally, the Constitution of India did not contain fundamental duties but today we have 11 fundamental duties.
    • Fundamental duties are applicable only to citizens and not to the aliens.
    • India borrowed the concept of Fundamental Duties from the USSR.

General Awareness
+1
What is the relation between Celsius and Kelvin temperature?
37° C = 273 K
0° C = 273 K
98.6° C = 273 K
0 K = 273°C
0° C = 373 K
Solution

The correct answer is 0° C = 273 K.

Key Points

  • The relation between Celsius and Kelvin temperature is  0° C = 273 K.
    • The number of degrees between absolute zero and the freezing temperature of the water is 273 on either temperature scale.
    • Therefore, the freezing temperature of the water is 273 degrees on the Kelvin temperature scale.
    • While the coldest temperature possible on the Celsius temperature scale is -273 degrees.

Additional Information

  • The temperature conversion formula from Celsius to Kelvin is:
    • K = C + 273.15
  • The temperature conversion formula from Kelvin to Celcius is:
    • C = K − 273.15
  • The temperature conversion formula from Fahrenheit to Celsius is:
    • \(C = {(F − 32) ×{ 5\over{9}}}\)
  • The Temperature Conversion Formula from Celsius to Fahrenheit is:
    • ​\(F = {C{9\over{5}}} + 32 \)
  • ​The Temperature Conversion Formula from Fahrenheit to Kelvin is:
    • \(K = {(F − 32) × {5\over{9}} + 273.15}\)

General Awareness
+1
When someone receives an eye transplant which of the following part of eye is being donated?
Retina
Pupil
Iris
Cornea
All of the above
Solution

The correct answer is the cornea.

  • When someone receives an eye transplant, the cornea of the eye is being donated.

Key Points

  • Functions of Parts

    • Cornea: The cornea is the outer transparent part of the eye that protects the eyes from external agents. 
      • Light enters the human eye through the cornea.
      • It is the part that is being transplanted while eyeing transplantation.
    • Iris:
      • It controls the pupil which controls the size of the pupil and the amount of light entering.
      • Iris gives distinct colour to the eyes. 
    • ​The eye lens is a spherical lens that forms an image of the object on the retina. 
  • The retina is a screen that sends information to the brain through the optic nerves.
    • Its function is to process the information gathered by photoreceptor cells and send them to the brain to decide what the image is.
  • The focal length of the eye lens is maintained by the ciliary muscles. 
  • It reduces the focal length by stretching itself to see nearby objects and relaxes to increase the focal length to see far objects.

Who was the Governor General of India during the Second Anglo-Mysore war?
Warren Hastings
William Bentinck
Lord Cornwallis
Lord Dalhousie
Lord Curzon
Solution

​The correct answer is 1 i.e Warren Hastings.

  • Warren Hastings (1772-1785) was the Governor General of India during the Second Anglo- Mysore War.
  • The Second Anglo-Mysore was fought between years 1780-1784.
  • Treaty of Mangalore ended the Second Anglo Mysore War with both parties agreeing for status quo and exchange of Prisoners.
  • The major event of war was the death of Hyder Ali in 1782 and crowing of Tippu Sultan.
  • Lord William Bentinck is also known as the father of western education in India.
  • He was the first Governor-General of India who was in office from 1833-1835 (earlier as Governor-General of Bengal from 1828-1833).
  • Lord Dalhousie was the youngest Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856.
  • He started the policy of Doctrine of Lapse.
  • He is credited for the formation of the Gurkha regiment.
  • He shifted the headquarters of Bengal artillery from Calcutta to Meerut.
  • Shimla was made the permanent headquarters of the army and the summer capital during his reign.

  • Adverbs of time tell us when an action happened, but also for how long, and how often. Adverbs of time are invariable.

    • Goldilocks went to the Bears' house yesterday.
    • I'm going to tidy my room tomorrow.

Directions: Choose the antonym of the word 'Cryptic'.
Lucid
Enigmatic
Arcane
Mysterious
Impenetrable
Solution

The correct answer is 'Lucid.'

Key Points

  • The word 'Cryptic' means Having a hidden meaning that is not easy to understand; mysterious or obscure.
    • Example: My journal is confused, almost cryptic on these matters.
  • Let's look at the meaning of the given options:-
    • Lucid - Expressed clearly; easy to understand.
      • Example: His explanation was lucid and to the point.
    • Enigmatic - Difficult to interpret or understand; mysterious.
      • Example: His reply was highly enigmatic.
    • Arcane - Understood by few; mysterious or secret.
      • Example: This argument may seem arcane to those not closely involved in the world of finance.
    • Mysterious - Difficult or impossible to understand, explain, or identify.
      • Example: His action was very mysterious.
    • Impenetrable - Impossible to understand.
      • Example: This history book is completely impenetrable to me.
         

Hence, the only possible answer is option 1.

Additional Information

  • The synonyms of the word 'Cryptic' are "Enigmatic, Arcane, Mysterious".

English Comprehension
+1

Direction: Given below is a sentence that may or may not be grammatically or contextually incorrect; different parts of the sentence are given as options. Choose the part that contains an error as your answer. If the sentence is error-free, mark option 5, i.e., 'No error,' as your answer.

Many word in the English language are derived from Latin, including the word "derive."

Many word in the English
language are derived
from Latin, including
the word "derive."
No error
Solution

The correct answer is option 1.

 Key Points

  • Option 1 i.e. "Many word in the English" is erroneous.
  • The word "word" should be pluralized to "words" to make the sentence grammatically correct. 
  • This change ensures subject-verb agreement, as "many" is a plural quantifier that should be paired with the plural noun "words."
  • Hence, "Many word in the English" is the correct answer.
  • The correct sentence would be: Many words in the English language are derived from Latin, including the word "derive."

 

Additional Information

"Much," "many," and "more" are words used to quantify or describe the quantity of something, but they are used differently based on whether you are talking about countable or uncountable nouns.

  • Much:
  • "Much" is used with uncountable nouns to indicate a large amount or degree.
    • Example:
    • There is too much sugar in this coffee.
    • I don't have much time to finish the report.
  • Many:
  • "Many" is used with countable nouns (nouns that can be counted individually) to indicate a large number or quantity.
    • Example:
    • How many apples are there in the basket?
    • I have seen many movies this month.
  • More:
  • "More" is used with both countable and uncountable nouns to indicate a greater quantity or degree than what is already present.
    • Examples:
    • Can I have more milk in my cereal? (uncountable)
    • I want to read more books this year. (countable)

  • The expression originated from military marksmanship training. Regarding this, the more competent marksman had the right and responsibility to call the shots.

English Comprehension
+1

Directions: The given question has one blank indicating that something has been omitted. Choose the word for the given options that could fit in the blank correctly.

You would scarcely expect her to know that,________?
Aren't you?
Wouldn't you?
Would you?
Do you?
Don't you?
Solution

The correct answer is Would you?.

Key Points

  • The adverbs never, rarely, seldom, hardly, barely, and scarcely have a negative sense. Even though they may be in a positive statement, the feeling of the statement is negative. We treat statements with these words like negative statements.
  • So the question tag is normally positive.
    • Ex: He never came again, did he?
           She can rarely come these days, can she?
  • Hence, option 3 is the correct answer.
     
Thus the correct sentence is: You would scarcely expect her to know that, would you?
Additional Information 
  • Question tags are short questions at the end of statements.
  • They are mainly used in speech when we want to: confirm that something is true or not, or to encourage a reply from the person we are speaking to.
  • Question tags are formed with the auxiliary or modal verb from the statement and the appropriate subject.
  • A positive statement is followed by a negative question tag.
    • Jack is from Spain, isn't he?
    • Mary can speak English, can't she?
  • A negative statement is followed by a positive question tag.
    • They aren't funny, are they?
    • He shouldn't say things like that, should he?

English Comprehension
+1

The question below contains five scattered segments of a sentence. Indicate the sequence which correctly assembles the segments and completes the sentence.

A. the truth is that

B. is no better time to

C. be happy than now

D. for happiness and there

E. no preconditions are necessary

BCDEA
DEABC
CADEB
DBCEA
AEDBC
Solution

The correct answer is AEDBC.

Key Points

  • A is the part that establishes the beginning of the matter,i.e., ' The truth is that '. Hence, it will be the first part after rearrangement.
  • Part E states that 'no preconditions are necessary' that is in continuation with part A. Hence, E follows A.
  • Part D refers to the fact that to be happy, we require no preconditions. So, part D follows E.
  • Part B talks about the best time to be happy, so it must come after part D, which talks about the conditions.
  • Part C states it's better to be happy now. Hence, E follows A.

​

Correct rearrangement of segments is -  The truth is that no preconditions are necessary for happiness and there is no better time to be happy than now.

Hint

  • While solving jumbles, one must first look for any independent sentences/segments or the option which establishes the subject matter.
  • Then, one must look for connections between the sentences/segments.
  • Some sentences/segments might have some concluding notion. So these parts will always be at the end.

​

English Comprehension
+1

Direction: Given below is a sentence that may or may not be grammatically or contextually incorrect; different parts of the sentence are given as options. Choose the part that contains an error as your answer. If the sentence is error-free, mark option 5, i.e., 'No error,' as your answer.

My hard work paid off, and I was excited to receive a perfect scores.

My hard work paid
off, and I was
excited to receive a
perfect scores
No error
Solution

The correct answer is option 4.

 Key Points

  • Option 4, "perfect scores," is erroneous. 
  • The correct form should be "a perfect score" because the subject is referring to a singular accomplishment (receiving a perfect score), not multiple scores. 
  • "Score" should be singular to match the singular article "a" that precedes it, making the sentence error-free.
  • Hence, "perfect scores" is the correct answer.
  • The correct sentence would be: "My hard work paid off, and I was excited to receive a perfect score."

 

Additional Information

  • Use of articles a, an, and the: 
  • Article 'a' is used before nouns that begin with a consonant sound.
    • For Example - 
    • I have a book in my purse.
    • (Here, article 'a' is used before the noun 'book' because it begins with a consonant sound)
  • Article 'an' is used before nouns that begin with a vowel sound.
    • For Example - 
    • Do you want an apple for breakfast?
    • (Here, the article 'an' is used before the noun 'apple' because it begins with a vowel sound)
  • Article 'the' is used before both singular and plural nouns when the noun is specific.
    • For Example - 
    • I saw the play you are talking about.
    • (Here, the article 'the' is used before the noun 'play' because it is the specific play that is being talked about)

  • The word 'Facilitate' means To make something possible or easier. (किसी बात को संभव या आसान बनाना)
    • Example: According to the contract, a mediator will facilitate the settling of our dispute.
       

Hence, the correct answer is option 5.

Complete Sentence: As a real estate agent, my mother often helps facilitate deals between property sellers and buyers.

Additional Information

  • Let us explore  the other options:
    • Legitimate means Allowed by law. (विधिसंगत, क़ानून से मान्‍य; वैद्य)
    • Tenable means Able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection. (आलोचना आदि का सामना करने में समर्थ; तर्कसंगत,तर्कसम्मत)
    • Hate means To have a very strong feeling of not liking somebody or something at all. (व्‍यक्ति या वस्‍तु के प्रति अत्‍यधिक अरुचि होना; घृणा करना)
    • Inadequate means Not enough; not good enough. (अपर्याप्त, नाकाफ़ी; अयोग्‍य)

English Comprehension
+1

In the following questions, the sentence has been given in Active/Passive Voice. From the given alternatives, choose the one which best expresses the given sentences in Passive/ Active Voice.

How many friends did you invite? 

How many friends were invited by you?
How many friends are inviting by you?
How many friends were invited with you?
How many friends are invited by you?
How many friends was invited by you?
Solution

Correct option - 1

Since, the given sentence is in active voice. So, we need to convert it into passive voice. Now, the sentence is in simple past tense. The tense remains same while converting it in any voice. Hence, options 2 & 4 are eliminated. Now, the verb is used according to the subject in the passive voice. The friends is a plural noun. Hence, option 5 is eliminated. Now, we know by is used in a passive voice. So, option 3 is eliminated. Thus , option 1 is the correct answer.

Correct sentence - How many friends were invited by you?

English Comprehension
+1

Directions: Which of the following phrases given below in the options should replace the phrase that is underlined in the sentence to make it grammatically correct? If the sentence is correct and does not require any correction mark 'No correction required' as your answer.

It is about time we tell you that you should start preparing for the exam sincerely.

told you that
had tell you that
will tell you that
have told you that
No correction required
Solution

The correct answer is option 1.

Key Points 

The underlined phrase 'tell you that' is incorrect. 

  • Rule:
  • It’s time + subject + past verb form [This expression refers to the present moment.]
  • Therefore,
  •  the sentence would be correct if “tell you that” is replaced by “told you that”.
  • Correct Sentence :
    • It is about time we told you that you should start preparing for the exam sincerely.

Hence, option 1 is the correct answer.

Important Points

  • We can use the expression it’s time + subject + past verb form to refer to the present moment.
  • Example:- Gosh! It’s almost midnight. It’s time we went home.
    • Not: It’s time we go home.
  • It’s time with a verb in the to-infinitive form can refer to the speaker and the listener together.
  • Example:- Come on. It’s time to start packing. We have to leave in two hours. (or It’s time we started packing.)​

English Comprehension
+1

Directions: Which of the following phrases given below in the options should replace the phrase that is underlined in the sentence to make it grammatically correct? If the sentence is correct and does not require any correction mark 'No correction required' as your answer.

The opaque nature of intrinsic values comes with fact that it is difficult for even the most seasoned investors to pinpoint future events.

comes at the 
comes within the
comes from the
comes on a
No correction required
Solution

The correct answer is option 3.

Key Points  

The underlined phrase 'comes with' is incorrect. 

  • The error in the phrase can be corrected if we add the article 'the' before the word 'fact'
  • From the given options 'comes from the' will be the most suitable phrase replacement both grammatically and contextually.
  • From -
  • It is used to refer to the place where someone or something starts or originates.
    • For Example - 
    • She picked the flowers from her garden.
  • It is used to show who sent or gave something to somebody and also used to show somebody’s position or point of view.
    • For Example - 
    • The view from my room is spectacular.
  • 'From' is used when making or recognizing a difference between two people or things.
    • For Example - 
    • Even though the colour is somewhat similar, my dress is very different from yours.
  • Hence, the phrase 'comes with' will be replaced by 'comes from the' to make the sentence grammatically correct.
  • Correct Sentence :
    • The opaque nature of intrinsic values comes from the fact that it is difficult for even the most seasoned investors to pinpoint future events.

Hence, option 3 is the correct answer.

Additional Information 

  • Within: inside (something).
    • Example:- "the spread of fire within the building"
  • At: expressing location or arrival in a particular place or position.
    • ​Example:- "they live at Conway House"
  • On: physically in contact with and supported by (a surface).
    • ​Example:- "on the table was a water jug"

97
English Comprehension
+1

In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the five alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.

She said to her uncle, “I will meet you at the station tomorrow.”

She said to her uncle that she will meet you at the station tomorrow.
She told her uncle that she would meet him at the station the next day.
She told to her uncle that she would meet you at the station the next day.
She told her uncle that she will meet him at the station the next day.
She said to her uncle that she will be meeting him at the station tomorrow.
Solution

The correct answer is option 2 i.e. 'He told his uncle that he would meet him at the station the next day.'

Key Points

  • The given sentence is in Direct Speech. 
  • The process of transformation in the indirect speech is as follows:
    • Here, in the given question 'said to' will be changed into 'told' because the reporting speech has an object. 
    • The conjunction 'that' will be added and comma and inverted commas will be removed. 
    • The pronoun 'I' will be changed into 'he' because the first person pronouns are changed according to the subject of the reporting verb. 
    • 'will meet' will be changed into 'would meet'. 
    • The second person pronoun 'you' will be changed into 'him' because it is changed according to the object of the reporting verb. 
    • Lastly, the adverb 'tomorrow' will be changed into 'the next day'. 
  • Therefore, as per the points mentioned above, we find that the correct answer is Option 2. 
    ​

Correct Sentence: She told her uncle that she would meet him at the station the next day.


Additional Information

  • Change in adverbs and determines in Direct To Indirect Speech. 
     
Adverbs in 'direct speech' Adverbs in 'indirect speech'
Now Then
Today That day
Here There
This  That
These Those
Ago Before
Today That day
Tomorrow The next day

 

  • The following table will enable us to know how tense changes into Indirect speech:
     
Direct Speech Indirect Speech
Present simple (Subject + V1st + Object) Past simple (Subject + V2 + Object)
Present continuous (Subject + is/am/are + V1 + ing + Object) Past Continuous (Subject + was/were + V1 + ing + Object)
Present perfect (Subject + has/have + V3 + Object) Past perfect (Subject + had + V3 + Object)
Past simple (Subject + V2 + Object) Past perfect (Subject + had + V3 + Object)
Past Continuous (Subject + was/were + V1 + ing + Object) Past perfect continuous (Subject + had been + V1 + ing + Object)
Future simple (Subject + will/shall + V1 + object) Present Conditional (Subject + would + V1 + object)
Future Continuous (Subject + will/shall + be + V1 + ing + Object) Conditional Continuous (Subject + would + be + V1 + ing + Object)

English Comprehension
+1

The question below contains five scattered segments of a sentence. Indicate the sequence which correctly assembles the segments and completes the sentence.

A. satisfaction may or may not 

B. and the perceived expectancy

C. lead to high performance  

D. depending on the perceived 

E. availability of valued outcomes

BCAED
CDEAB
DEABC
ACDEB
EADBC
Solution

The correct answer is ACDEB

Key Points

  • A is the part that establishes the subject of the matter,i.e., 'satisfaction may or may not. Hence, it will be the first part after rearrangement.
  • Part C states that satisfaction may or may not be the reason to perform higher. Hence, C follows A.
  • Part D refers to the factors on which the it depdends. So, part D follows C.
  • Part E talks about first factor,i.e. 'availability of valued outcomes', so it must come after part D, which talks about factors.
  • Part B talks about the second factor which will come after E and begins with connector 'and'. Hence, E follows A.

​

Correct rearrangement of segments is - Satisfaction may or may not lead to high performance depending on the perceived availability of valued outcomes and the perceived expectancy.

Hint

  • While solving jumbles, one must first look for any independent sentences/segments or the option which establishes the subject matter.
  • Then, one must look for connections between the sentences/segments.
  • Some sentences/segments might have some concluding notion. So these parts will always be at the end.

​

Directions: The question below contains five scattered segments of a sentence. Indicate the sequence which correctly assembles the segments and completes the sentence.

A. political unrest in Pakistan, it has caused

B. severe economic challenges for months

C. the 2022–2023 Pakistani economic crisis

D. due to which food, gas, and oil prices have risen

E. is an ongoing economic crisis and part of the 2022–2023

AEDCB
CEABD
DCBAE
EDCBA
BCDEA
Solution

English Comprehension

Direction: Read the given passage carefully to answer the following questions. Each question will have five alternatives as its answer. Choose the correct option as your answer.

Neeraj Chopra scripted another glorious chapter by becoming the first-ever Indian to secure a gold in the World Athletics Championships in Budapest on Sunday. It was Neeraj’s second and India’s third medal after long jumper Anju Bobby George opened the account in 2003. Neeraj, the first Indian Olympic champion athlete, hurled the javelin to 88.17m in his second attempt to achieve the crown in a highly competitive field, also comprising Commonwealth Games champion Arshad Nadeem, who took the silver, the first-ever Worlds medal for Pakistan, with 87.82m. Neeraj, who recorded his season-best 88.77m in the qualification round, continued his unbeaten streak this year to not only improve upon his 2022 Worlds silver in Eugene but also become the third athlete after Jan Zelezny and Andreas Thorkildsen to win the World and Olympics gold. He formally led India’s javelin revolution on a global stage as compatriots, Kishore Jena (84.77m) and D.P. Manu (84.14m), took fifth and sixth spots. Neeraj’s feat made India one of the three countries that earned their maiden yellow metal. The Indian men’s 4x400m relay team members (Muhammed Anas, Amoj Jacob, Muhammed Ajmal and Rajesh Ramesh) ran out of their skin to create a new Asian record (2:59.05) and enter the final. Ultimately, they finished fifth. Woman steeplechaser Parul Chaudhary set a new national mark of 9:15.31.

However, the long jumpers, triple jumpers, hurdler Jyothi Yarraji and steeplechaser Avinash Sable’s below-par show brought disappointment. Even though leading athletes have been caught doping this year, Neeraj, Chaudhary and the relay team’s achievements will encourage the Indians for the Asian Games and 2024 Olympics. The mediocre performance of several athletes is a matter of concern for the Athletics Federation of India and the Sports Ministry and calls for an appraisal of the training. The World Championships witnessed several spectacular performances, including the U.S. 4x400m mixed relay team’s world record. While the U.S. continued to dominate despite a reduced tally of 29 medals, including 12 gold, Canada improved to claim six, including four gold. With China not getting a single title, Asia’s gold count dipped from five to three. U.S. sprinter Noah Lyles became the first male after Usain Bolt to win the 100m, 200m and men’s 4x100m relay titles, Kenyan superstar Faith Kipyegon won a 1500m and 5000m double and Spaniard Alvaro Martin and Maria Perez swept the race walks, coinciding with the Chinese and Japanese walkers’ failure, to make the edition exciting. The World Athletics would do well to promote track and field sport across the globe.

Which of the provided words has a similar meaning to 'revolution' as used in the passage?
Evolution
Repetition
Endurance
Recession
Transformation
Solution

The correct answer is option 5.

Key Points

  • To answer this question, let's understand the meanings of the given word and all the words given as options - 
  • Revolution - a dramatic and wide-reaching change in conditions, attitudes, or operation (आमूल परिवर्तन)
    • For Example - 
    • The technological revolution transformed how we communicate and access information.
  • Evolution - any net directional change or any cumulative change in the characteristics of organisms or populations over many generations (विकास)
    • For Example - 
    • The evolution of birds led to various specialized beak shapes for different diets.
  • Repetition - the act of repeating, or doing, saying, or writing something again (दुहराव)
    • For Example - 
    • Practicing piano requires repetition to improve accuracy and skill over time.
  • Endurance - the ability to endure an unpleasant or difficult process or situation without giving way (सहनशीलता)
    • For Example - 
    • Her endurance in the marathon was impressive, finishing despite the challenging weather.
  • Recession - a slowdown or a massive contraction in economic activities (मंदी)
    • For Example - 
    • During the recession, many people lost their jobs and struggled financially.
  • Transformation - a marked change in form, nature, or appearance (परिवर्तन)
    • For Example - 
    • Exercise brought about a remarkable transformation in her overall health and energy levels.
  • After understanding all the given words, we can conclude that the word which is most similar in meaning to the given word "Revolution" is "Transformation."
  • Therefore, the correct answer is "Transformation."

Neeraj Chopra scripted another glorious chapter by becoming the first-ever Indian to secure a gold in the World Athletics Championships in Budapest on Sunday. It was Neeraj’s second and India’s third medal after long jumper Anju Bobby George opened the account in 2003. Neeraj, the first Indian Olympic champion athlete, hurled the javelin to 88.17m in his second attempt to achieve the crown in a highly competitive field, also comprising Commonwealth Games champion Arshad Nadeem, who took the silver, the first-ever Worlds medal for Pakistan, with 87.82m. Neeraj, who recorded his season-best 88.77m in the qualification round, continued his unbeaten streak this year to not only improve upon his 2022 Worlds silver in Eugene but also become the third athlete after Jan Zelezny and Andreas Thorkildsen to win the World and Olympics gold. He formally led India’s javelin revolution on a global stage as compatriots, Kishore Jena (84.77m) and D.P. Manu (84.14m), took fifth and sixth spots.     • For Example -

    • For Example -

    • For Example -

    • For Example - 
    • The loss of such a talented artist is truly lamentable.

English Comprehension

Read the following passage and answer the question that follows:

India’s gross Goods and Services Tax (GST) revenues grew almost 11% this November to nearly ₹1.46 lakh crore. While this is only the tenth such occasion since the onset of the GST in July 2017 that revenues have been over ₹1.4 lakh crore, that mark has been consistently topped for nine months now. The two highest GST monthly receipts so far — over ₹1.67 lakh crore in April and ₹1.51 lakh crore in October — were partly bolstered by taxpayers filing quarterly returns. Discounting periodic spikes in compliance, one can possibly peg the ₹1.4 lakh crore as the new normal baseline for monthly GST revenues hereon. With almost ₹12 lakh crore already in the GST kitty this year, the Government is likely to end up with a not-insignificant surplus over its Budget. This is welcome fiscal headroom, especially since the Centre’s subsidy bill on items such as fertilizers and foodgrains has also surpassed the Budget math, and may help the Government stick to its fiscal deficit target. On the flip side, however, November’s GST revenues are not an enthusing indicator about the state of the broader economy.

The 10.9% overall GST revenue growth in November, reflecting transactions undertaken in October when the major festivals, including Deepavali, occurred — is the slowest uptick recorded since June 2021. November revenues were the lowest in three months and marked a nearly 4% dip from October’s kitty. E-way bills generation, broadly indicating outflow of goods from producers to the wholesale and retail supply chains, dropped a steeper 8.6% sequentially, perhaps as factories recorded higher downtimes amid extended holidays. One would have expected festive consumption to spike the GST intake despite the e-way bills decline, as inventories were already built up in anticipation. That effect appears muted and it is quite puzzling that revenues contracted year-on-year in as many as seven States, including Gujarat and Kerala. Growth in inflows from domestic transactions slowed from 18% in October to 8% last month, while revenues from imports of goods rose to 20% in November — a possible sign that the consumption recovery remains uneven, with goods consumed by higher income groups seeing a better rebound. December’s post-festival GST collections could yield a clearer picture, both on the sustainability of the headline revenue numbers and the growth trajectory of the economy. The GST Council, meeting this month after another prolonged gap, must expedite long-awaited action on pending issues to bolster compliance, and not lose sight of the larger, currently-deferred plan to rationalise the tax rates with a view to spur broad-based and sustainable consumption growth.

What may be deduced from the gross GST income for the month of November?
In terms of GST income, it was the best-performing month ever.
1.4 lakh crore can be pegged as the new normal baseline.
The revenue of upcoming months will be lower than 1.4 lakh crore.
Major festivals never affect the tax revenue.
None of the above
Solution

The correct answer is "1.4 lakh crore can be pegged as the new normal baseline."

Key Points

  • Refer to the following line from the passage:
    • Line 1 and 2 of paragraph 1: India’s gross Goods and Services Tax (GST) revenues grew almost 11% this November to nearly ₹1.46 lakh crore. While this is only the tenth such occasion since the onset of the GST in July 2017 that revenues have been over ₹1.4 lakh crore.
    • Line 3 of paragraph 1: Discounting periodic spikes in compliance, one can possibly peg the ₹1.4 lakh crore as the new normal baseline for monthly GST revenues hereon.
  • ​From the highlighted part in the above given lines, it can be concluded that option 2 is correct.

Hence, the correct answer is option 2.

Quantitative Aptitude
+1
A, B, P and Q are points on the circumference of a circle with centre O. If angle AQB is 60°. then which of the following can be the value of angle APB?
160°
30°
90°
60°
None of these
Solution

Given:

A, B, P, and Q are points on the circumference of a circle with center O.

Angle AQB is 60°.

Concept Used:

Angles made by same chord on the circumference of the circle are equal.

Calculation:

Angle AQB = 60° makes by chord AB on the circumference of the circle.

Also angle APQ makes by the same chord AB on the circumference of the circle.

So by the property of chord

Angle AQB = angle APQ = 60° 

∴ Option 4 is the correct answer.

 

113
Quantitative Aptitude
+1
The printed value on the book is Rs. 3800, a book seller offers a 10% discount on it. If he still earns 20% profit, then the purchase price of the book is (in rupees) -
2870
2880
2850
2860
None of these
Solution

Given:

The printed value on the book is Rs. 3800.

A book seller offers a 10% discount on it.

He still earns 20% profit.

Concept Used:

Profit percentage = (Profit / Cost price) × 100 

Calculation:

Let's assume the purchase price of the book is P rupees.

The book seller offers a 10% discount on the printed value of Rs. 3800, which means the selling price is 90% of the printed value.

Selling price = 90% of Rs. 3800 = (90/100) ×  3800 = Rs. 3420

Since we have a profit of 20%, we can write the equation as:

20 = (Profit / P) × 100

To find the profit amount, we can rearrange the equation:

Profit = (20 × P) / 100

We know that the selling price is the purchase price plus the profit:

Selling price = Purchase price + Profit

Rs. 3420 = P + ((20 × P) / 100)

Now, let's solve this equation to find the purchase price:

Rs. 3420 = P + (0.2 × P)

Rs. 3420 = 1.2 × P

P = Rs. 3420 / 1.2

P = Rs. 2850

Therefore, the purchase price of the book is approximately Rs. 2850.

∴ Option 3 is the correct answer.

114
Quantitative Aptitude
+1
When an item is sold for 408 rupees, then there is a loss of 15%. Find the purchase price of the item. (In rupees)
420
440
460
480
None of these
Solution

Given:

An item is sold for 408 rupees.

Loss of 15%.

Concept Used:

Loss percentage = (Loss / Cost price) × 100 

Calculation:

Let's assume the purchase price of the item is P rupees.

Since we have a loss of 15%, we can write the equation as:

15 = (Loss / P) ×  100

To find the loss amount, we can rearrange the equation:

Loss = (15 ×  P) / 100

We know that the selling price is the purchase price minus the loss:

Selling price = Purchase price - Loss

408 = P - ((15 ×  P) / 100)

Now, let's solve this equation to find the purchase price:

408 = P - (0.15 ×  P)

408 = 0.85 ×  P

P = 408 / 0.85

P ≈ 480

Therefore, the purchase price of the item is approximately 480 rupees.

∴ Option 4 is the correct answer.

115
Quantitative Aptitude
+1
Simplify the following expression: \({1-\sin A\over \cos A}+{\cos A \over 1-\sin A}\)
2 cos A
2 tan A
2 sec A
2 sin A
None of these
Solution

Given:

\({1-\sin A\over \cos A}+{\cos A \over 1-\sin A}\)

Concept used:

\(cos^{2}\ \theta+sin^{2}\ \theta =1\)

\(sin\ \theta = \frac{1}{cosec\ \theta }\)

Calculation:

\({1-\sin A\over \cos A}+{\cos A \over 1-\sin A}\)

\({(1-\sin A)^2+\cos^2 A\over \cos A( 1-\sin A)}\)

= \(sin^{2}A+cos^{2}A+1-2sinA\over (1-sinA)cosA\)

We know,

\((cos^{2}A+sin^{2}A=1)\)

= \(2-2sinA\over(1-sinA)(cosA)\) 

= \(2(1-sinA)\over (1-sinA)cosA\)

= \(2\over cosA\)

= 2 sec A

Hence, the correct answer is an option 3).

Quantitative Aptitude
+1
The length of the base of a triangle is 10 cm and its altitude from the same base is 8 cm. What is the area of the triangle? 
30 cm2
40 cm2
50 cm2
80 cm2
None of these
Solution

Given:

Base = 10 cm

Altitude = 8 cm

Concept Used:

Area = (1/2) ×  base ×  altitude

Calculation:

Substituting these values into the formula, we get:

Area = (1/2) ×  10 cm ×  8 cm

Area = 5 cm × 8 cm

Area = 40 cm²

Therefore, the area of the triangle is 40 cm².

∴ Option 2 is the correct answer.

The ratio of the volume of first and second cylinder is 32 ∶ 9 and the ratio of their heights is 8 ∶ 9. If the area of the base of the second cylinder is 616 cm2, then what will be the radius of the first cylinder?

20 cm
28 cm
36 cm
None of these
Solution

Volume ratio = 32 ∶ 9

Ratio of their heights is 8 ∶ 9

Area of the base of the second cylinder is 616 cm2

Concept Used:

Volume of cylinder = πr2h

Calculation:

Height of the cylinder can be written as 8h and 9h

⇒ Volume of second cylinder = 616 × 9h

⇒ r = 28

Quantitative Aptitude
+1
The downstream speed of a boat is 25 km/hr and the speed of stream is 3 km/hr. What will be the total time taken by the boat to cover 100 km downstream and 57 km upstream?
10 hours
7 hours
10.5 hours
8 hours
None of these
Solution

Given:

The downstream speed of a boat is 25 km/hr.

The speed of stream is 3 km/hr.

Calculation;

The speed of the boat in still water 

25 km/hr - 3 km/hr = 22 km/hr.

When the boat is moving downstream 

22 km/hr + 3 km/hr = 25 km/hr.

When the boat is moving upstream 

22 km/hr - 3 km/hr = 19 km/hr.

The boat will take 100 km/25 km/hr = 4 hours.

The boat will take 57 km/19 km/hr = 3 hours.

So, the total time taken by the boat to cover 100 km downstream and 57 km upstream is 4 hours + 3 hours = 7 hours.

∴ Option 2 is the correct answer.
